paper_abstract: Recently, the single machine scheduling problem with (p-s-d) setup times is getting more attentions from academic researchers and industrial practitioners The past-sequence-dependent setup times an., proportional to the length of already scheduled jobs It Is shown that for a number of objective functions this scheduling problem. can be solved in O(n log n) time In this paper, we extend the analysis of the problem with. the total absolute difference in completion times (TADC) as the objective function This problem is denoted as 1/s(psd)/TADC in [1] Let s([j]) and p([J]) be the setup time and processing time of a job occupying positron J in the sequence respectively, and s([J]) is defined as s([J]) = gamma Sigma(J-1)(i=1) p[r], where gamma is a normalizing constant In this paper, We present a parametric analysis of gamma on the 1/s(psd)/TADC problem. We show analytically the number of optimal sequences and the range of gamma in which each of the sequence is optimal We prove that the number of optimal sequences is {1 + Sigma(x)(k=1) (2k)} if n is odd, and {1 + Sigma(x)(k=1) (2k - 1)} if n is even The value of x is left perpendicular n/2 right perpendicular - 1 when n is odd, and x is n/2 when is even The number of optimal sequences depends only on n, the number of jobs, and not on gamma We also show analytically that when gamma > (n-3)/2(n-2), the optimal sequence unique and Is obtained by placing the longest job in first position and the rest of the yobs in SPT order in positions 2 to n.
paper_title: A PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS FOR SINGLE MACHINE SCHEDULING WITH PAST-SEQUENCE-DEPENDENT SETUP TIMES
